Award.AwardTitle: Development, Deployment, and Validation of a Differential Abospbtion Lidar for Water Vapor Profiling in the Lower Troposphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers at Montana State University (MSU) have developed a novel diode-laser-based differential absorption lidar (DIAL) for water vapor profiling in the lower troposphere. This instrument, which until now has been laboratory-based, utilizes external cavity diode lasers in conjunction with a tapered semiconductor optical amplifier to produce a widely tunable DIAL laser transmitter capable of accessing many water vapor lines of varying strength. This is the first diode-laser-based DIAL instrument to successfully demonstrate both nighttime and daytime water vapor profiling capabilities, and has the potential to spearhead cost-effective deployment of networks of similarly-designed sensors. The supported research will test and evaluate development of a field deployable DIAL instruments for unattended long-term data collection in a variety of geographic/meteorological settings. The semiconductor laser-based instrument, which incorporates many cost-effective off-the-shelf components, will be modified to operate over a wider temperature range. The instrument will be deployed at three field sites for data collection on the order of thirty days at each site. The long term data sets collected during these field deployments will be compared with in situ water vapor measurements for validation purposes. The intellectual merit of this effort rests is development of a more sophisticated and cost-effective DIAL instrument that can be deployed in a ground based network for climate and weather research and forecasting applications.

Broader impacts of this effort include potential impacts of improved monitoring and forecasting of local and mesoscale weather effects (e.g., thunderstorm development) that are highly dependent on accurate knowledge of atmospheric water vapor content in the layer nearest the earth's surface. Close cooperation with personnel at the National Center for Atmospheric Research will speed integration of developed technologies into the suite of instruments available for NSF-supported researchers. Training of a graduate student will also be enhanced through direct involvement in this effort.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lowest several kilometers of the atmosphere, called the troposphere, contains the majority of the atmospheric water vapor.  The distribution and amount of water vapor in the troposphere affects both our weather and climate and the ability to measure the distribution of water vapor in real time is needed for improved weather forecasting, particularly for severe weather events such as thunderstorms.  

     The recently completed research effort has led to the development of a low-cost differential absorption lidar (DIAL) that utilizes diode laser technology for continuously monitoring water vapor in the troposphere.  This diode laser based DIAL instrument operates in an eye-safe mode and extended autonomous observations with this instrument have been conducted over several months at various locations around the United States demonstrating the ability of this instrument to monitoring water vapor in the lower troposphere. Data from this instrument has been compared to other observational instruments including radio-sondes, a micro-wave radiometer (MWR), and the Atmospheric Emmitted Radiance Interferometer (AERI) by outside scientists to confirm the the measurements made by the DIAL instrument will satisfy the needs of the weather forecasting and climate science community.

     The completion of this research project has the potential to impact the broader public in meaningful ways.  First, the development of a low cost observational instrument for profiling water vapor, one of the key properties that define the state of the atmosphere, can help improve weather forecasting, partcularly severe weather events more accurately.  As research with this instrument continues, work to incorporate it into the next generation of weather stations will continue.  econd, the development of this low-cost, eye-safe, autonomous instrument has the potential, through modifications, to continuously monitor the atmospheric temperature distribution in the troposphere providing another needed measurement that will help define the state of the atmosphere and improve weather forescasting.  Third, the deployment of this instrument at field campaigns including the Plains Elevated Convection at Night (PECAN) and Front Range Air Polution and Photochemistry Experiment (FRAPPE) are helping understand how our atmosphere and climate system work.  Finally, work to commercialize tecyhnology based on this research project is underway.
